chapter: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question:
Question 1: A 60-year-old man with hemiplegia is brought to the OPD for a follow-up visit. He suffered 
from a stroke 2 months ago. On examination, he was found to have slurred speech and a 
positive Babinski sign. Which other examination findings are expected to be seen in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The given patient has slurred speech and a positive Babinski sign, which is suggestive of an upper 
motor neuron lesion (UMN lesion). Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are a feature of UMN 
lesions. The distal muscle groups are affected more than the proximal muscles and the axial muscles are 
spared (as the anterior corticospinal tracts supplying the axial muscles have bilateral 
representation) in UMN lesions. Axial muscles are involved when the lesion is severe or bilateral. Hypertonia in the form of spasticity is seen in the upper motor neuron lesions. Fasciculations and 
hypotonia are features of lower motor neuron lesions.
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with pseudobulbar 
palsy?
questions.explanation:
Jaw jerk is brisk in pseudobulbar palsy. Bilateral corticobulbar lesions produce pseudobulbar palsy. This condition is characterized by 
dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, emotional lability, bilateral facial weakness, and brisk jaw jerk. Damage to lower motor neurons of the cranial nerves in the brainstem is called bulbar palsy. 
Depressed jaw jerk is seen in bulbar palsy. Pseudobulbar palsy is analogous to UMN lesions exhibiting hyperreflexia. Bulbar palsy is 
analogous to LMN lesions exhibiting hyporeflexia. 1058 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: All of the following drugs have to be stopped before a lumbar puncture, except:
questions.explanation:
Aspirin and other NSAIDs can be continued in a patient who is scheduled to undergo a lumbar 
puncture (LP). These drugs have not shown an increased risk of developing spinal hematomas. 
Hence an LP can be performed in patients receiving these drugs. Options A and B: Abciximab and eptifibatide are Gp IIb/ IIIa inhibitors. Platelet aggregation 
remains abnormal following the discontinuation of these drugs. LP, spinal and epidural 
procedures must be avoided until the platelet function is normal. Option D: Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor. LP should be avoided in patients receiving 
this drug due to the risk of developing epidural or spinal hematomas. Other factor Xa inhibitors, 
namely, fondaparinux and apixaban must also be held prior to LP, spinal and epidural 
procedures.

questions.question:
Question 6: A pathologist received a blood-tinged CSF sample for evaluation. The sample was subjected to 
centrifugation and the following finding was observed. What is the least likely differential 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows xanthochromatic CSF on centrifugation. This is unlikely with a traumatic 
tap. A traumatic tap has clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation. Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap 
can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the drawn CSF 
sample. In such situations, centrifugation of the sample distinguishes the two. • Clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation supports a traumatic tap. • Xanthochromatic supernatant suggests SAH. Xanthochromatic supernatant may be present in the following conditions: • In Liver disease, due to elevated bilirubin levels. 1059 
Sold by @itachibot • When CSF protein concentration is elevated. • In subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), RBCs are present in the CSF long enough for them to 
undergo lysis. This releases hemoglobin which is converted to bilirubin, thus staining the CSF 
yellow.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 23-year-old woman presents with nausea, fever, and neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture is 
ordered. All of the following are effective strategies to prevent post-lumbar puncture 
headache in this patient, except:

options.b: Insertion of a needle with bevel pointed upwards
options.c: Replacement of stylet prior to removal of the needle

questions.explanation:
The use of a 22 gauge needle (or smaller) can reduce the incidence of post-dural headache after 
lumbar puncture. Effective strategies that reduce the incidence of PDPH include: • Use of small-diameter needle (22-gauge or smaller) • Use of atraumatic needle (Sprotte and others) • Replacement of stylet prior to removal of the needle • Insertion of a needle with bevel oriented in a cephalad to caudad direction (when using a 
stranded needle) Ineffective strategies: • Bed rest (up to 4h) following LP • Supplemental fluids • Minimizing the volume of spinal fluid removed • Immediate mobilization following LP The customary practice of remaining in a recumbent position post-LP is unnecessary. Studies 
have shown no benefit in terms of reducing the incidence of headaches.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with sudden onset speech difficulty, tremors, and 
difficulty in walking. He is noted to have a wide stepping gait. He is a known hypertensive but 
is not adherent to treatment. Where is the lesion most likely to be seen on neuroimaging?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cerebellar ataxia, hence the lesion is most likely to be 
seen in the cerebellum. Cerebellar ataxia can be caused due to an acute vascular event such as 
infarction or hemorrhage. Wide stepping gait, a broad-based unstable gait is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Few other 
notable gait abnormalities are: • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness A few of the cerebellar signs include: • Dysdiadokinesia / dysmetria 1060 
Sold by @itachibot • Ataxia • Nystagmus • Intention tremor • Speech - slurred or scanning • Hypotonia
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency ward following an acute episode of inability to 
move his lower limbs. Examination findings are given below. Which of the following 
investigations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute paraparesis. This is caused most commonly by an 
intraspinal lesion. A negative Babinski reflex and flaccidity are suggestive of a lower motor neuron 
lesion. Hence, the most appropriate among the given investigations for acute paraparesis with 
LMN signs is a spinal MRI. Spinal causes of acute onset paraparesis include: • Injury to the spinal cord • Thrombosis of anterior vertebral artery • Hematomyelia • Prolapsed intervertebral disc
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question:
Question 10: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a 
comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate was 1054 
Sold by @itachibot >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do?
questions.explanation:
Ruling out glycemic extremes is the first step in the evaluation of this patient who is in a coma as 
most of the causes of coma are metabolic in origin and with appropriate treatment are completely 
reversible. In this elderly patient, with no other relevant history, the most likely cause of coma is diabetic 
ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, or even hypoglycemia (which may present with 
hypertension). Other options : The patient presents with tachycardia which is not a sign of raised intracranial 
pressure(bradycardia, altered respiratory pattern, raised systolic blood pressure) and hence 
starting iv mannitol (option 3) to reduce intracranial pressure or doing a CT (option 4) to rule out 
intracranial space-occupying lesion is not required. The patient is a known case of hypertension which may cause hypertensive encephalopathy due to 
cerebral edema and would present with a similar history and signs of raised intracranial pressure 
giving antihypertensive (option 2) medications would treat the condition but it is not the first step 
as metabolic causes are more common and have to be addressed first. Coma is defined as a deep sleep-like state from which the patient cannot be aroused.Coma could 
be due to: • Metabolic and toxic encephalopathies, where brain imaging will be normal 1061 
Sold by @itachibot • Meningitis syndromes • Diseases with prominent focal signs like stroke, or hemorrhage Urgent intervention is needed to prevent further brain damage. It is done by providing 
supplemental oxygen, intravenous thiamine (at least 100 mg), and intravenous 50% dextrose in 
water (25 g) empirically. It is crucial to measure baseline serum glucose levels before 
administering glucose. The initial examination includes evaluating the general appearance,vitals, breath sounds, 
response to stimulation, pupil size and responsiveness, and any abnormal posturing or 
movements. In trauma cases, the neck should be stabilized until ruling out cervical spine fracture. 
Airway protection and intravenous access is necessary. Immediate therapeutic intervention should be done for hypotension, significant hypertension, 
bradycardia, arrhythmias affecting blood pressure or marked hyperthermia. Signs of meningeal 
irritation or fever indicate the need for urgent lumbar puncture. Fundus examination for 
papilledema and a CT scan of the brain should be performed prior to lumbar puncture in 
comatose patients.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is the most common cause of autonomic storm?
questions.explanation:
Brain injury is the most common cause of autonomic storm and typically follows severe head 
trauma and postresuscitation anoxic-ischemic brain injury. An autonomic storm is an acute state of sustained sympathetic surge which can cause alterations 
in BP and heart rate, body temperature, respiration, and sweating. Other causes include: • Spinal cord injury • Drugs and toxins (phenylpropanolamine, cocaine, amphetamines, and TCA's; tetanus; and less 
often, botulinum toxin) • Autonomic neuropathy • Chemodectomas (e.g., pheochromocytoma). • Guillain-Barré syndrome can produce a moderate autonomic storm.
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question: Question 12: What is the minimum Glasgow coma scale-pupils score for a head injury?
questions.explanation:
The GCS-P score allows a minimum score of 1. The Glasgow coma scale – pupils score (GCS-P) was described in response to the wish for a single 
index combining the coma scale with pupillary reactivity as a reflection of brainstem function. Its 
possible values range from 1 to 15, reflecting an extended range of severity, and may be 
particularly useful in relating to prognosis. The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the pupil reactivity score (PRS) from the Glasgow coma 
scale (GCS) total score: 1062 
Sold by @itachibot GCS-P = GCS - PRS The minimum score in GCS is 3.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident 
while driving a motorcycle. During the evaluation, the patient opens his eyes in response to 
voice and says inappropriate words. He is unable to move his right arm but extends his left 
arm when a painful stimulus is applied to his right arm. What is the GCS score of this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The GCS score of the patient described is 8 (E3 V3 M2). In the case elaborated above, the score allotted is : • Eye-opening to speech—3 • Inappropriate words—3 • Extensor response of the upper limb in response to painful stimuli—2 Patients scoring a GCS of 3 or 4 have an 85% chance of dying or remaining vegetative. However, scores >11 indicate only a 5–10% likelihood of death or vegetative state and 
an 85% chance of moderate disability or good recovery.
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

response to a loud voice, localizes pain, and is confused and disoriented. What is the GCS

questions.explanation: In this patient, GCS is E3M5V4 • Eye-opening to loud voice - 3 • Motor response localizes pain - 5 • Verbal response is confused and disoriented - 4

questions.question:
Question 15: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and 
abnormal flexion?
questions.explanation:
The GCS score is E2VNTM3. In this case: • Eye-opening to pain: E2 • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is 
denoted as 'not testable/NT'. Earlier in intubated patients, the V score was denoted as VT. 
According to the current update, the V score should be VNT. • Abnormal flexion: M3

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient is brought to the emergency room after he was brutally beaten during a mugging 
incident. He is unresponsive even to painful stimuli and is apneic; however, he does have a 
pulse. Which of the following clinical findings would exclude a diagnosis of brain death?
questions.explanation:
Constricted pupils would rule out brain death. Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac 
activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means. 1063 
Sold by @itachibot In brain death, the pupils are usually midsized or maybe dilated. However, constricted pupils are 
not seen. The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings: • Absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or 
other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing) • Unresponsiveness to any stimuli • Brainstem damage, as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction • Absent corneal, gag, and oculovestibular reflexes • Absent sucking or rooting reflexes • Absent cough with tracheal suctioning • Apnea, indicating medullary destruction • The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question:
Question 17: The family of an ICU patient who is in a coma has given consent for organ donation. An 
apnea test is performed. Lack of respiratory effort at what arterial pCO2 level will aid in 
confirming brain death?
questions.explanation:
To declare brain death, apnea is confirmed if no respiratory effort has been observed in the 
presence of arterial pCO2 levels of 60 mmHg (apnea test is positive). Destruction of the medulla leads to complete and irreversible apnea. Demonstration that apnea is 
due to medullary damage requires that the PCO2 be high enough to stimulate respiration during a 
test of spontaneous breathing. An apnea test is conducted to confirm that there is no respiratory effort in the presence of a 
sufficiently elevated arterial PCO2. Apnea testing can be done safely by the use of preoxygenation 
with 100% oxygen prior to and following removal of the ventilator. CO2 tension increases 
~0.3–0.4 kPa/min (2–3 mmHg/min) during apnea.
questions.chapter_heading: General Neurology  Brain Death  and GCS

questions.question: Question 18: Clinical criteria for brain death include all except:
questions.explanation:
Clinical criteria for brain death does not include absent spinal cord reflexes. Deep tendon 
reflexes/spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord is intact. Criteria for brain death: • Coma - Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli • Absence of brainstem reflexes - Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc. • Apnea - Absence of spontaneous respiration at arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60mm Hg 1064 
Sold by @itachibot Seizures and Epilepsy
